prospects.name: Endurance 1.5
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

prospects.name: Strides & Drills
prospects.description:
This is a technique-focused session designed to develop your agility, stability, range of motion, and foot speed. There is no focus on heart rate zones so you may choose to leave your monitor at home for these sessions. Between sets of each drill, you should jog/walk easily to fully recover between the efforts. While these efforts shouldn’t be too taxing on you, the key is perfect form, so you want to be hitting each one rested enough that you can maintain great form for the duration. You should take a bit of extra rest between techniques, again to ensure you are rested and can nail the form. Before starting the workout, familiarize yourself with the format for high knees, butt kicks, skipping, carioca and strides. Find a flat track, field, or 50-100m of open space to perform this workout (football and soccer fields are great for this).

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-up:**

Start off with 5-10 minutes of easy jogging/walking.

High Knees: 2-3 sets of 50m high knees.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Take short strides, bringing your knees up high enough that your upper legs are parallel to the ground. Focus on achieving high knees AND quick turnover, or performing as many reps as possible in a short distance.

**Butt Kicks:**

2-3 sets of 50m butt kicks.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- This should actually look similar to a high knee drill, but with the heels coming up to touch the bottom of your butt. Take short strides while using your hamstrings to lift your heels up beneath your butt. Your knees should come up in front of your body while pulling your heels up beneath your hips, rather than keeping your quads and knees below and in line with your hips.

**Skipping:**

3-4 sets of 50m skipping.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between.

- Focus on a high knee drive and swinging your arms at your sides like you would when running.

**Carioca:**

4 sets of 30m Carioca in each direction (8 total).

Rest for 20 seconds between direction changes (at your discretion).

- For this drill, you need to face sidewise to the direction you want to go. Start off moving to the right. Bring your left knee up and across your body and put your left foot in front of your right foot. Step your right foot to the right so it is parallel with your left leg again (at this point you should be positioned in the same direction and orientation that you were at the start. Next step your left leg behind your right leg, again so it lands on the right side of your right leg. Then bring your right leg back across your body, once again ending up in the starting position. Repeat this pattern for 25-30m.

**Strides:**

2-3 sets of 60m; Gradually build effort from RPE 3-8.

Easy jog/walk for 30-60 seconds between. These are comprised of a steady acceleration over 60-80m up to 5k pace. The goal is to increase speed after each step, so you are reaching maximum speed at the end of the 60-80m stretch. You want to focus on keeping your shoulders, neck, and jaw relaxed while maintaining strong knee drive, straight and compact arm swing, planting the feet beneath the hips, and fast turnover.

​

High Knees + Butt Kicks:

Finish these drills with one set each of 50m high knees and butt kicks.

​

**Cool-down:**

Walk or jog for 5 minutes to cool down.

In case you need to brush up on your running [drills](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ)

prospects.name: Cadence Builds
prospects.description:
One of the best sessions for neuromuscular training, this drill asks you to progressively build from a cadence of 90 RPM to your MAX over 30 seconds, recover, and repeat several times. Cadence builds improve how you recruit your leg, gluteal, and core muscles throughout your pedal stroke by progressing to your maximal cadence. By reaching your highest cadence possible, you are training the 'on/off' switch in each muscle group to not only work faster but to have less overlap with your other muscle groups. This session trains your hamstring muscles to 'turn off' when your quads 'turn on' and vice-versa, resulting in a more efficient pedal stroke at both high and low cadences.

​

**LEARN MORE**

Listen to The Knowledge podcast, by Wahoo Sports Science - The Benefits of High Cadence Training: [https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence](https://wahoosystm.com/BenefitsofHighCadence)

prospects.name: Technique A
prospects.description:
In case you need to brush up on your other [technique definitions or drills](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterSwimDrills).

For help understanding your swim workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/SwimSessionFAQ).

​

Good swimming technique is the key to efficient swimming. Today's session is a low intensity workout that challenges you with a series of drills designed to reinforce proper technique that will make you a more efficient, powerful and faster swimmer.

​

**Warm-Up**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE 2 -- Z1

​

**Activation 1**

Number of Sets: 4

Interval Distance: 25m Drill of choice

The goal of a Drill set is not to swim at any given pace, but instead focus on proper form. Choose a drill or focus on one of these key points for each 25m interval:

- \*Body position- swim on horizontal plane
- \*Enter in front of shoulder- preventing cross over
- \*Breathe early- prevent wide stroke- elbow is always widest point
- \*Elbow is always the highest point of the stroke
- \*Back of hand always faces direction of travel
- \*Fingers to point at the bottom of pool
- \*Initiate your stroke from the hips

Recovery: 10 seconds rest

​

**Activation 2**

Number of Sets: 1

Interval Distance:

200m Pull @ RPE 3-4 -- Z2

- This set eliminates the use of your legs. It requires a buoy that you can swim with between your legs. The buoy will keep your body in the correct orientation. By removing your legs from the drill you will be required to only use your arms. This will help you focus on efficient form and making the most of each stroke!

Recovery: 20 seconds rest

​

**Main Effort**

The following should all be done at a moderate pace (RPE 2-4 -- Z1-Z2), with enough rest between that you can focus on proper form

Interval 1: 150m of One Arm Freestyle drill

- This is an old standby. Put your non-pulling arm out in front of your body and swim with only the opposite arm. Take some time to watch the arm that is pulling. Feel your elbow directly above your hand and that you are pulling right down the midline of your body. Split your body in half with your fingertips. Your emphasis should be on power and efficiency not on speed.
- See how few strokes you can take to get down the pool.
- Once you have it mastered, you can leave the non-pulling arm at your side.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 2: 200m of 3/4 Catch Up drill

- A variation to catch-up that takes us closer to the full stroke. Another way to describe this is almost catch-up. Take a stroke with the right hand, wait until this hand is almost all the way through recovery and then start your pull with the left. This creates a very rhythmic feel, almost like skating through the water. Take your pull and ride the glide from it. When you lose speed, take your next pull. Want a good example of this? Watch Olympic replays of the Aussies, particularly Ian Thorpe. He races like this drill. Efficiency is your goal.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 3: 200m of Elbow-Hip-Elbow drill

- A variation on side glide kick. The same goals apply balance, body roll, and head position during breathing. Start on either side with one arm extended out front, and the other at your side. With the fingers of the hand at your side, touch the elbow of your upper arm, then your hip, and then the elbow again. Now take your stroke or three strokes. Kick and glide and repeat.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 4: 150m of Fist Drill

- Swim freestyle with your hands in fists. This is going to force you to get your forearms involved in the stroke because they have more surface area than your hands. Keep your elbow high under the water. Your forearm, from elbow to fingertips should be perpendicular to the bottom of the pool. Again, watch Ian Thorpe. You will feel like you are slipping through the water which is normal, however, the more water you feel like you are pulling the more efficient you are getting.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Interval 5: 200m of Zipper Drill

- This drill is done by pulling the fingers up the side of the body until they come into the armpit. The point of this is to keep a nice high elbow on recovery and to force the body to roll. Many use the Fingertip drag drill to accomplish this but we prefer this drill because the body roll essentially gives this drill a dual purpose.

Recovery: 20-sec rest

Repeat until full swim time is completed

​

**Cool Down**

200m stroke of your choice @ RPE < 2 -- Z1

​

**Total Distance**

1600m

prospects.name: Endurance  2
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 2
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: The workout accompanying this film is a recovery session. It's a very low-intensity ride, with your power remaining at or below 50% of FTP (an RPE less than 2.5 on a scale from 1 to 10) and your heart rate in Zone 1. The intensity and cadence targets will vary throughout this session to keep it interesting, but not so much that it distracts you from the story.

prospects.name: FTP Progression 2: 5 x 7
prospects.description:
As the title suggests, this is the second addition to our FTP series, designed to help you improve your threshold. This workout is simply 5 repeats of 7 minutes at 96-100% of FTP with 3 minutes of easy recovery, making for a 60-minute session with 35 minutes of riding at FTP.

​

You should be getting comfortable with your fresh power numbers from your recent Full Frontal test and feel like you're gaining strength and fitness from completing the first FTP Progression workout a few times. This session has added one minute to the FTP intervals and removed a minute from the recovery sections, getting you closer to that final version of 5 x 9 min efforts with only 3 minutes recovery in between.

​

**Warm Up**

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 6.5 -- 85% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 7.75 -- 105% of FTP -- HR >105%

3 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort** x5

Work: 7 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR >105%

Rest: 3 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

2 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

30 seconds @ RPE 1.5 -- 40% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Split Brick Race Pace 120/90
prospects.description:
This cycling session is part of a bike-run brick and is meant to be paired with one of the "Split" Brick Running sessions.

Today's workout is a double brick, which means that after each of the bike sessions you will do a brick run. This gives you the opportunity to practice T2, so make sure to have your running gear set up beforehand. When you finish the first bike session, dismount, transition, and complete the first brick run (details can be found in each of the “split brick” run workout descriptions ). Upon finishing the run, take a few moments to eat and drink if necessary then hop back on the bike for the second set.

This workout is a great opportunity to practice a negative split pacing technique. Begin the first cycling session at 55% of FTP to get warmed up and gradually increase to 75%. Aim to hold 75% of FTP for at least the last 90 minutes. On the second cycling set, begin at 70% and increase to 75% after 10-15 minutes.

​

Since this is a race pace workout, it is a great time to practice your nutrition strategies prior to race day. Aim to consume 50-75g of carbohydrates per hour. Note that the maximum fuel your body can process in 60 minutes is 90 grams, but only if 60g comes from glucose and 30g from fructose. Unless you know the exact sugar breakdown of your nutrition do not aim for 90g per hour.

It is a good idea to weigh yourself before and after this session so you can determine if you are drinking enough. Losing 1-2 pounds of water weight during this session is okay, any more than that and you need to reassess your hydration plan.

​

**Warm-Up **(Only prior to first cycling session)

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: Your first Run session

Set 1: 2 hours @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

Set 2: 90 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

​

Recovery:** **

NA

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

NA - Straight into Run 2!

prospects.name: Wahoo Frontiers 2023
prospects.description:
🎬 Film (2023): Discover the incredible stories behind some of this year's top Wahooligan athletes:

**Chelsea Sodaro** is the reigning IRONMAN World Champion, but beyond her athletic prowess, Chelsea's greatest source of pride is her ability to show up for herself and her daughter. Chelsea shares the power of finding her voice, advocating for female athletes, and why motherhood is her most significant victory to date. Follow Chelsea's journey to defending her World Champion title in 2023.

​

**Heather Jackson:** As one chapter closes, a new one opens. After 15 years as a professional triathlete, Heather Jackson decided to challenge herself in new ways, build a fresh community, and push her own and other's expectations of what is humanly possible. In June, Heather tackled the Unbound Gravel 200, often hailed as the "Super Bowl" of gravel bike racing, and the iconic Western States Endurance Run, the world’s oldest 100-mile trail race. Facing these demanding events with just a two-week gap between them, the question looms: how will Heather approach her most ambitious goal yet?

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

​

[Here's how to turn off on-screen graphics for the best viewing experience.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterInspiration)

prospects.name: To Get To The Other Side
prospects.description:
While you might think the only way to improve your FTP is to ride at, or above, your existing FTP, that isn't always the case. Your body can only handle so much time above FTP in any given week (or month, for that matter). But that doesn’t mean you should sit around doing nothing the rest of the time.

​

Your body is most efficient at clearing out lactate and other metabolic byproducts at 80-95% of FTP. This is one of the few sessions where you can consistently sit at that intensity and let your body churn away at this nice, efficient effort level. It's the ideal workout to end a hard, three-day block or add in during a rest week. It will give your body a little training stimulus while still allowing it to recover from whatever tortures you've recently put it through.

prospects.name: Split Brick Race Pace 45/30

​

This run session is part of a bike-run brick and is meant to be paired with one of the "Split" Brick Cycling sessions.

Today's workout is a double brick, which means that before each of your run intervals you will do a bike session. This gives you the opportunity to practice T2, so have your running gear set up before you start your bike rides. When you finish the first bike session, dismount, transition, and complete the first brick run (details below). Upon finishing the run, take a few moments to eat and drink if necessary and transition back to the bike for the second set.

​

**Warm Up**

First cycling session

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: Second cycling session

Set 1: 45 minutes @ RPE 5-6 -- 110-120% of RTP --HR <90% (Z3)

Set 2: 30 minutes @ RPE 5-6 -- 110-120% of RTP --HR <90% (Z3)

Recovery: NA

​

**Cool Down**

After Set 2: 5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <75% (Z1)

prospects.name: Split Brick Race Pace 90/60
prospects.description:
This cycling session is part of a bike-run brick and is meant to be paired with one of the "Split" Brick Running sessions.

Today's workout is a double brick, which means that after each of the bike sessions you will do a brick run. This gives you the opportunity to practice T2, so make sure to have your running gear set up beforehand. When you finish the first bike session, dismount, transition, and complete the first brick run (details can be found in each of the “split brick” run workout descriptions ). Upon finishing the run, take a few moments to eat and drink if necessary then hop back on the bike for the second set.

This workout is a great opportunity to practice a negative split pacing technique. Begin the first cycling session at 55% of FTP to get warmed up and gradually increase to 75%. Aim to hold 75% of FTP for the last 60-75 minutes.  On the second cycling set, begin at 70% and increase to 75% after about 15 minutes.

​

Since this is a race pace workout, it is a great time to practice your nutrition strategies prior to race day. Aim to consume 50-75g of carbohydrates per hour. Note that the maximum fuel your body can process in 60 minutes is 90 grams, but only if 60g comes from glucose and 30g from fructose. Unless you know the exact sugar breakdown of your nutrition do not aim for 90g per hour.

It is a good idea to weigh yourself before and after this session so you can determine if you are drinking enough. Losing 1-2 pounds of water weight during this session is okay, any more than that and you need to reassess your hydration plan.

​

**Warm-Up **(Only prior to first cycling session)

5 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 2

Rest Between Sets: Your first Run session

**Interval**

Set 1: 90 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

Set 2: 60 minutes @ RPE 5 -- 70-75% of FTP -- HR <90% (Z3)

Recovery: NA

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

NA - Straight into Run 2!

prospects.name: Endurance  2
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are just times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high, your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week, but only if you do it right!

​

Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles." Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted. So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like?

For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70% is ok, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in mid to low Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR, up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can, for most this is 80-90rpm and your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster. You will have to trust us on that one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions! Or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

Warm-Up

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

Main Effort

Number of Sets

5

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats per Set

1

Interval: 10 minutes @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

​

Extra Volume

N/A

​

Cool Down

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Costa Blanca: Puerto de la Vall de Ebo (Recharger Ride)
prospects.description:
This is an active recovery ride built with purpose. Low-intensity endurance work is paired with brief high-cadence neuromuscular activations to keep the nervous system awake without creating new fatigue. You’ll stay well below threshold throughout, allowing your body to absorb previous hard sessions and prepare for what’s ahead.

​

Set on the peaceful roads leading to the summit of Port de la Vall d’Ebo, this ride promotes circulation, technique, and mental reset. It’s ideal after race days or big training blocks — a smart session that helps you recover better, so you can train harder tomorrow. No ego, no watts chasing — just intentional recovery done right.

​

[**Wahoo Route**](https://www.strava.com/activities/13996505846)

​

_Your Host: There are few people who know the mountains and roads of Europe better than Wahoo Ambassador Michael Cotty. As founder of The Col Collective, Mike has made a career out of riding, filming, and telling the story of epic rides and mountains across the continent. As your On Location co-creator and host, Mike's engaging character, curious mind, and friendly nature will have you cueing up your next ride with him before you've even finished the cool-down._

prospects.name: Serbia Upside Down Ep. 3
prospects.description:
🎬 Film: Serbia. A small country in the Balkan Peninsula that hides some of the most beautiful natural wonders and unique cultural heritage in this part of the world. Yet it remains unknown to many. Only the alternative, curious and brave plan their journeys in this hidden gem. However, a small self-organized crew from Serbia and Germany set a mission to discover and reveal those stunning natural creations of Serbia. On a bicycle. In just five days, they traversed 450 kilometers across six mountains of Western Serbia, and climbed around 11,000 meters to film and produce what you are about to experience.

​

🚴 Workout: This is a great way to watch a compelling documentary while developing your baseline aerobic fitness. The intensity of this workout will vary mostly between 60-70% of FTP, with heart rate remaining entirely in zone 2. This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing.

prospects.name: Tempo Build: 1 x 60
prospects.description:
Tempo sessions are always a great time to work on pace control, especially Tempo efforts longer than 30 minutes. We are taking that pacing demand a bit further in this session by forcing you to slightly increase your effort as time goes on. This is referred to as a "Negative-Split", meaning the second half is faster (or you hold a higher power) than the first half.

​

While you might question the benefit of doing "easier" tempo efforts, the truth is when riding between 80% and 100% of FTP your body processes oxygen and metabolites at nearly the same rate. Holding a higher power will give you a higher single day training stimulus, but looking at the big picture that can have its drawbacks. Mainly the fatigue those harder sessions cause, which requires easier workouts the days before and after. Sticking to the Tempo targets gets you nearly the same training stimulus while allowing you to hit harder sessions the rest of the week.

​

This session contains a single 60-minute tempo effort, broken into three 20-minute segments. You will spend the first 20-minutes at 80% of FTP, the next 20 at 84%, and the final 20 at 87%. By the time you hit the last 10-minutes of this effort, that 87% will feel much harder than it should. Another way of thinking about this one, if you were to reverse the order, and start at 87%, what you would likely find is that your RPE stays fairly consistent for the entire effort, even though the power targets are dropping.

​

Overheating, not drinking enough, being under-fueled and mental fatigue will all play a factor in how you feel in that final block. They will also impact your heart rate. While these power targets are usually associated with Zone 3 heart rate, many people will see their heart rate climb into low Z4 if they are not hydrating properly, or have inadequate cooling. This can be a great session to act as a "wake up call" on any poor training habits you might have so take note and aim to address those issues during your next workout.

​

**Warm Up**

30 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 7 -- 95% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

1 minute @ RPE 8 -- 105% of FTP -- HR <100%

7 minutes @ RPE 2.5 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: NA

Rest between sets: NA

Interval repeats per: NA

**Interval**

20 minutes @ RPE 6 -- 80% of FTP -- HR <100

20 minutes@ RPE 6.5 -- 84% of FTP -- HR <100%

20 minutes @ RPE 7 -- 87% of FTP -- HR <100%

​

**Extra Volume**

45 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 50% of FTP -- HR <70%

prospects.name: Tapers
prospects.description:
When it comes to "peaking", or performing at your absolute best on a given day, the key is nailing your Taper. The term "Taper" refers to how you train in the week or so before your target event to ensure you deliver your best performance. Generally, tapering means reducing your total training volume but continuing to hit some high-intensity efforts. While there are individual variations in the best way to taper, this session has been used by countless professionals leading into the biggest races of their lives -- athletes like World Champions Rohan Dennis and Flora Duffy.

​

With 3 sets of micro-intervals (40/20s, 30/30s, and 20/40s) you will hit your system with just enough intensity to keep your legs sharp and responsive, without adding any real fatigue. Outside of those 3 sets of micro-intervals, this session is purposefully short and easy. This is a preparation session, not a training session! After all, your event is just around the corner and all of the important training is behind you. Riding harder or longer today will do absolutely nothing to increase your fitness by event day; in fact, all that would do is increase your fatigue, which will only hurt your performance. Rather, this session makes sure your body is humming along and ready to perform on the big day.

prospects.name: Endurance  1
prospects.description:
The goal of this workout is to help develop your baseline aerobic fitness. While we are all about the High-Intensity Interval Training that most of our videos dish out, there are times in a well-structured training plan that a proper Endurance/Base ride is just what your body needs.

​

This session will add minimal fatigue to your system, while still giving your aerobic engine the workload it needs to continue progressing. Steady Long Endurance rides are one of the best ways to cap off a long 2 or 3-week training block when your fatigue is high and your legs are tired, but you have just a bit more to squeeze out of yourself before you take your rest week. Shorter Endurance rides (like this one) can fit in both a hard week of training and a recovery week. That is, only if you do it right! Most people ride too hard when they head out for their "base miles."

​

Truth be told, a proper Zone 2 ride, especially one under 90 minutes should not leave you fatigued or your legs wasted.

So what does a "proper" Zone 2 ride look like? For 90% of the ride, you should stay between 55% and 65% of your FTP, at times going up to 70%, but not over. (To spice things up, we have broken this session into 10-minute segments alternating from 60 to 65% of FTP.) Your heart rate should be sitting in low to mid Zone 2 heart rate, which is 70-80% of LTHR up to 85% of LTHR, but not for long. It would be best if you held the highest comfortable cadence you can; for most this is 80-90rpm. Also, your RPE should be a 2-4 on a scale of 1-10.

​

Sounds simple right? It's actually one of the harder sessions to get right because you spend most of the time questioning why you are riding so easy, and if this is really going to make you fitter and faster, but you will have to trust us on this one! When you see this session in your Training Plan, follow these instructions, or you might just pay for it when your next hard session comes around.

​

**Warm Up**

5 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets: 1

Rest Between Sets: 10 minutes @ RPE 3.5 -- 60% of FTP -- HR <80%

Interval Repeats Per Set: 2

**Interval**

prospects.name: Openers
prospects.description:
Whether you have power testing, a group ride you want to smash, that event you have been training all winter for, or even just a fun route you want to have a great ride on, this is the perfect session to do the day before. The key to this session is just enough time right around threshold, with sufficient recovery between efforts and a handful of sprints to prime all of your systems for tomorrow's event.

​

**Warm-Up**

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <65%

1 minutes @ RPE 3 -- 55% of FTP -- HR <70%

1 minute @ RPE 4 -- 65% of FTP -- HR <80%

1 minute @ RPE 5 -- 75% of FTP -- HR <85%

30 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 90-95% of AC (130-190% of FTP)

4 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <70%

​

**Main Effort**

Number of sets: 3, all unique

Rest Between Sets: 8 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

**Set 1**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 3 minutes at @ RPE 7 -- 90% of FTP --HR <95%

**Set 2**

Interval Repeats per set: 1

Interval: Effort: 2 minutes @ RPE 7.5 -- 100% of FTP -- HR <100%

**Set 3**

Interval Repeats per set: 3

Interval: Effort: 30 seconds @ RPE 9 -- 95% of MAP (110-130% of FTP)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 45% of FTP -- HR <75%

​

**Extra Volume**

N/A

​

**Cool Down**

6 minutes @ RPE 1.5 -- <45% of FTP

prospects.name: Running Primers
prospects.description:
Just like the Primers Cycling Video, this session is about getting your body prepped and ready to run your absolute best tomorrow. That means you either have a fitness test, race, or another intense intense workout tomorrow, so make sure to cool down properly and re-fuel after this session!

​

For help understanding your run workout and calculating your pace zones, please see [this article](https://wahoosystm.com/RunningSessionFAQ).

Learn how to perform your [**Running Drills**](https://support.wahoofitness.com/hc/en-us/articles/4404080091922-Running-Drills) here.

​

**Warm-Up**

10 minutes @ RPE 3-4 -- 145-120% of RTP -- HR 70-87% (Z2)

​

**Main Effort**

Number of Sets 1

Rest Between Sets NA

Interval Repeats Per set 4

Interval Effort: 60sec Accelerations from RPE 4 up to RPE 8 --120% of RTP to 90-100% RTP -- HR 90+ % (Z2-Z4b)

Recovery: 90 seconds @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

​

**Extra Volume**

NA

​

**Cool Down**

5 minutes @ RPE 2 -- 145% of RTP -- HR <70% (Z1)

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 01
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that develops your overall coordination and control._

​

As the first session in this progression, we introduce you to an integrated sequence of athletic movements. This mix may feel different and challenging..maybe even fun! Embrace it!

​

Please take your time, especially in this initial session. Start and stop the video to rewatch the demonstrations, if necessary, to ensure you understand the movement and grasp the range of motion. Finally, for the exercises that include a balance component, it will be ideal to keep your gaze fixed on a still object, not your screen.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Backbend w/ Arms overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Alternating-Step Under
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Low Skip In Place
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Tip Toe Walk
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Drop to Squat & Hold - Dbl. Leg
- Hop to Opposite Leg w/Hold
- Toe Touch

prospects.name: Run Focus 1
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this first routine in the sequence, we'll introduce you to some basic foundational movement patterns that will help improve your running by enhancing lower body and core stability as well as strength. The exercises are simple and the interval durations are short. Utilize the full duration of the session to focus on quality technique using the full range of motion. As the program progresses you'll complete more variations for longer periods, so dial in that good form now.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Squat w/ Hands Behind Head
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Kneeling Hip Drive Hands Up

- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Frog Crunch
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Bird Dog
- Pigeon Stretch
- Runner Stretch

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hips Side to Side
- High Plank to Pigeon Pose
- Plank with Leg Lifts
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Fast Lateral Lunges with Knees Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side

You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

In this second session, we'll build on the foundational movement patterns that you mastered in the previous routine. Run Focus 2 also includes new progressions to increase the number of activated muscle groups as well as some hopping moves to help challenge your hip and ankle stability.

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 02

_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Now that you’ve completed Level 1, it’s time to add a layer of neuromuscular coordination. This sequence includes balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping exercises - and combinations of those. You’ll even complete integrated exercises which involve single-leg challenges in various directions. Focus on controlled deliberate movements and solid landings to master this session.

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 03
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Ready for the third workout in the Dynamic Focus series? All athletes, including competitors in endurance sports, benefit from training that better helps you react to external factors in varying directions; people, wind, waves, inclines, and surfaces. This sequence will prime you for these variables with varying tempos. With a combination of exercises that integrate three-dimensional motion this session will keep your neuromuscular system primed and ready for anything, no matter what type of rubber you’re on.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this first routine in the sequence, we'll introduce you to some basic foundational movement patterns that will help improve your running by enhancing lower body and core stability as well as strength. The exercises are simple and the interval durations are short. Utilize the full duration of the session to focus on quality technique using the full range of motion. As the program progresses you'll complete more variations for longer periods, so dial in that good form now.

prospects.name: Full Body 06
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

At this level, we can begin to throw in more upper body and core work compared to previous Full Body sessions. The goal is not to develop big muscles in your arms and chest, but to build basic functional strength to help you improve stability and become a more well-rounded athlete.

​

This extra work is derived from more difficult variations of the foundation moves. While the added upper-body component will decrease the number of reps you can complete in a set, your primary goal remains to nail perfect form. Even though you've been at this for several weeks your nervous system is still learning these movement patterns. Keep focusing on completing the exercise correctly rather than moving quickly.

prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. prospects.name: Full Body 08
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

You’re progressing quite nicely. So nicely, in fact, that you’re ready for a more demanding session. This workout includes compound sets which are more difficult but, most importantly, more beneficial than simply doing more sets of a single move. This is because your nervous system has to work overtime to cope with the variety. The number of reps per set is also higher, which will help drive continuous improvement.

​

Since this is a longer session, you may experience considerable fatigue on your first time through. As a result, pay more attention to your form. Your body will want to use as little energy as possible, which can lead to some bad habits when hitting rep after rep of a single move. Thankfully, the constant variation of the compound sets forces you to stay engaged and helps you keep solid form from start to finish.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Sides

- Single-Leg Squat with Opposite Reach
- Lateral Lunge with Opposite Hand
- Lateral Lunge with Opposite Hand + Shoulder Press

Ready for the third workout in the Dynamic Focus series? prospects.name: Run Focus 1
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this first routine in the sequence, we'll introduce you to some basic foundational movement patterns that will help improve your running by enhancing lower body and core stability as well as strength. The exercises are simple and the interval durations are short. Utilize the full duration of the session to focus on quality technique using the full range of motion. As the program progresses you'll complete more variations for longer periods, so dial in that good form now.

​

**Included Exercises:**

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

Your posterior chain is responsible for back and hip extension as well as knee flexion. It is vital in maintaining optimal posture during cycling and running in addition to water position in swimming. In this first session, we introduce some basic movements that focus on the activation and stabilization of posterior chain muscles. These moves include a combination of eccentric (lengthening), concentric (shortening), and isometric (holding) contractions. They provide your body with the foundation for more demanding moves to come. This is also a good session to come back to if you feel like you could use a quick posterior chain activation or tune-up.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Split Stance Side bend w/ Arms Overhead
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Split Stance Hip Hinges
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Kneeling Hip Extension
- Quadruped w/ Cervical Extension
- Quadruped Chin Tucks
- Double Leg Hip Bridge
- High Plank w/ Alt. Arm Raise
- High Plank w/ Hip Abduction + Tap
- 45° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Lat Press on Wall-Reps
- 90° Reverse Fly w/ Reps
- Overhead Reverse Fly w/ Hold
- KickBacks from Toes
- Hamstring Hip Bridge
- Marching Hip Bridge
- Back Extension w/ opposite arm & leg raise
- Downward Dog
- Pigeon Stretch

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Overhead Shoulder Rolls
- Standing T-Spine Rotations
- Lat Press with a Hold
- Hip Hinges on the Wall
- 45 Degree Reverse Fly
- Wide Pushups
- Quadruped Pull-In with Hold
- Quadruped Push-Out with Hold
- Low Plank with Scapular Presses
- Low Side Plank with Toe Taps
- High Plank with Alternate Arm Raise
- Back Extensions
- Cervical Extensions
- Chin Tucks from a Quadruped Position
- Quadruped T-Spine Rotations
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Side-Lying T-Spine Arcs

prospects.name: Full Body 10
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This routine marks a big step up in duration -- including nearly 8 minutes of core work. That's right, you can have the strongest legs in the world, but without a solid core, you won’t be able to put down the power efficiently. As we continue to increase your leg strength, we need to make sure your core endurance improves as well.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Side to Side
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Reverse Lunge with Hands Over Head
- Backward Lunge
- Lateral Lunge with Extended Hands
- Single-Leg Squat with Hands Forward
- Single-Leg Squat with Hands Forward + Shoulder Press
- Goblet Squat
- Bulgarian Squat
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Hinge with Shoulder Press

- Quadruped with Arm Raise + Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts + Sliding
- High Plank with Leg Lifts
- Side Plank with Hip Raise
- Side Plank with Hip Drop
- Half Twists

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 03
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

Ready for the third workout in the Dynamic Focus series? All athletes, including competitors in endurance sports, benefit from training that better helps you react to external factors in varying directions; people, wind, waves, inclines, and surfaces. This sequence will prime you for these variables with varying tempos. With a combination of exercises that integrate three-dimensional motion this session will keep your neuromuscular system primed and ready for anything, no matter what type of rubber you’re on.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Runners Stretch-Alternating
- Around the clock Heel & Toe Taps
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Tip Toe Walk
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Single-Leg Hip Rotations
- Squat and Hold to Jump
- Backward Shoulder Rolls
- Low Skip In Place
- Tempo Squat

- Forward Shoulder Rolls
- Squat w/ Hands Behind Head

prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees
- Back Extension
- Quadruped with Leg Lifts
- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Run Focus 2
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In this second session, we'll build on the foundational movement patterns that you mastered in the previous routine. Run Focus 2 also includes new progressions to increase the number of activated muscle groups as well as some hopping moves to help challenge your hip and ankle stability.

​

**Included Exercises:**

- Squat Wide Stance Hands Forward
- Single leg Hip Hinge
- Squat w/ Hands Behind Head
- Recoil Hamstring Stretch
- Kneeling Hip Drive
- Kneeling Hips Side to Side
- Foot Circles
- Fire Hydrant
- Backward Lunge Arms on Hips
- Backward Shoulder Rolls
- Deep Squat w/Arms Crossed
- Single Leg Heel Raise
- Hip Hinge-Hands on Head
- Side Lunge to Knee Lift w/ Hold
- Tempo Hip Hinge
- Inchworm
- Hop to Opposite Leg w/Hold
- Frog Crunch
- Oblique Leg Lifts
- Back Extension w/ Arm & Leg raise
- Pigeon Stretch
- Runner Stretch

prospects.name: Run Focus 3
prospects.description:
The SYSTM Run Focus series of strength training sessions are designed specifically for runners to help improve performance and reduce the risk of injury. Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

Run Focus 3 adds an additional layer of difficulty to the foundational moves, with dynamic movements and sequences that help build balance and stability. There are also more integrated variations that incorporate the upper body for full-body activation. This session maintains the strong focus on glute and thigh musculature, as well as enhancing stability at the ankle and hip, and ensuring the engagement of the three-dimensional core.

prospects.name: Posterior Chain Focus 02
prospects.description:
_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

The second session in this series focuses on activating and strengthening key structural stability muscles and developing optimal tension throughout the body. To do this, we use a combination of isolated and integrated movements in a variety of body positions and build on the movements from Posterior Chain 1. We also introduce tempo movements that require extra focus on timing and eccentric loading. Even though this is only Level 2, you may find some of these moves difficult to perform. That's ok, take your time and focus on performing the moves correctly even if you have to pause the video.

prospects.name: Full Body 11
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

We’re going to continue to build strength endurance by adding longer sets than previous routines and increasing the number of single move variations you complete back-to-back. Not only will you be asked to do multiple versions of a foundational move, but we also include Compound Sets. That means you'll be doing those combinations in challenging sequences. This combination maintains the same muscular demand as completing multiple sets of the exact same exercise but places greater demands on your nervous system to maintain balance and stability.

​

prospects.name: Dynamic Focus 04
prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

​

The fourth sequence in this Dynamic Focus series challenges your neuromuscular coordination with longer intervals. Integrated exercises with balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping are all present. With a focus on stability toward the second half of the session, you’ll be forced to control your motion when tired. Your concentration and endurance will be pushed to maintain quality execution the entire time.

​

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands to Side
- High Plank
- Plank
- Hip Bridge
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands Up
- Standing Hip Drive with Hands to Side

_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Well done getting to this point! As you move through this session, really focus on keeping full control of your movements. You can only build strength in the muscles you can control. Also - because of the additional load, it's important that you’ve followed the progression and mastered the foundational exercises in the previous levels. One does not simply walk into Full Body 12. :)

​

Like the Previous Posterior Chain sessions, Level 3 targets the muscles of the back side of your body. However, this routine has a greater concentration on upper back and posterior shoulder strength than the earlier sessions. This more advanced combination of movements will challenge your stability and strength endurance. If you find yourself struggling with some of the moves late in the session it's ok to pause the video and take a breath. Your form is the most important thing here, so don’t push through and get sloppy.

prospects.description:
_Looking to improve your mobility, stability, power, and coordination? The Dynamic Focus series is a fun, unique, and valuable mix of balance, strength, and jumping exercises that_ _increase performance through stability, power, and coordination._

With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

With 30 minutes of work and an exciting array of 26 exercises, this is a solid workout. While we still run you through the paces on lower body moves, this session will hit your upper body and core quite hard. This ensures that you continue to build full-body strength and stability. Since, by now, you are ninja-level competent on every move (and since you only get gains when you give your body new training loads) we're going to push you by increasing the total number of reps across all the exercises. Get in there!

_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

Welcome to the second session in this series. We’re going to continue the focus on increasing strength in the chest, back, shoulders and arms. Many of the exercises will be familiar from Level 1, but you’ll likely find it a bit more challenging. That’s because we’ve made the durations a bit longer and the moves a little more complex. Challenge yourself to maintain quality repetitions throughout the sequence and strive for a full range of motion.

Each session offers a progressive set of integrated exercises that includes a focus on the lower body, posterior chain, and core, in addition to supplementary movements for the upper body.

​

In Run Focus 4 you'll complete the foundational moves with longer, more challenging combinations to help improve your dynamic stability and muscular endurance. We also added strength exercises that incorporate a mobility component, particularly at the hips. prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

**Exercises Included:**

- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Over Head
- Kneeling Hip Drive - Hands Side to Side
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Bent Leg Tip at the Hip
- Goblet Squat
- Single-Leg Squat
- Backward Lunge
- Hip Hinge with Reach
- Hip Bridge with Reps
- Push-Up on Knees

- Plank with Leg Lifts

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

_The primary objective of the Posterior Chain Series is to activate and strengthen the muscles on the back side of your body. This includes everything from your powerful glutes, hamstrings, and calves to the postural muscles of your upper back and neck._

​

In this routine, you’re going to keep building on the moves that you’ve mastered in the previous sessions (you have mastered them, right?). It’s time to increase the external load, though, so you’ll need a band to redirect tension and build more eccentric loading into the movements. The longer sets and difficult combinations will be challenging - embrace it! Also, even though the focus is Posterior Chain you will find integrated core moves throughout the session. Let’s rock!

By this point, you’re no longer struggling with single-leg balance and stability, which allows us to really focus on building raw muscular endurance in your lower body. ​

Now that you’ve completed Level 1, it’s time to add a layer of neuromuscular coordination. This sequence includes balance, unilateral drills, lower body strength, and jumping exercises - and combinations of those. You’ll even complete integrated exercises which involve single-leg challenges in various directions. Focus on controlled deliberate movements and solid landings to master this session.

prospects.name: Upper Body Focus 01
prospects.description:
_The primary goal of this series is to increase strength in the major muscles of the chest, back, shoulders and arms. We’ll also focus on improving mobility, stability, and flexibility in the upper body. So get ready for great body-weight-based routines that focus on quality repetitions, endurance holds, and range of motion challenges._

​

As the first session in this series, we’re going to introduce you to some basic upper body movements. This sequence will be beneficial for endurance sports where you need some upper body strength and improved posture, such as swimming, cycling (especially MTB and Cyclocross), and running. To help ensure overall strength, this routine incorporates some core muscle exercises and you may find some portions of the sequence difficult. No problem! Take your time to understand the movement. Pause the video if you need to and embrace the process of mastering new exercises.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you?  [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

prospects.name: Recovery Session B
prospects.description:
This session is designed to keep your body familiar with the basic movements of strength training without adding any extra fatigue to your system. This keeps your body adapted while allowing it to fully recover. To make the most out of your strength gains, you need to balance the hard work with adequate recovery. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend completing a supplementary Yoga Session after this video. Something like Improving Posture, Shake Off the Day or Recovery Booster would be perfect.

​

**Exercises Included**

- Kneeling Hip Drive with Hands Over Head

prospects.name: Recovery Session A
prospects.description:
These recovery sessions are easy enough that you get the rest you need, but work you hard enough that your body continues to adapt to the new demands you place on it. You might see these sessions as too short and too easy to be beneficial, but just like a proper recovery spin, active recovery is infinitely better than doing nothing at all. Given how short this session is, we strongly recommend also doing a Yoga Session in the app first. Something like Mobilize and Activate, Balance and Agility, or Full Body Mobilization.

​

**Exercises Included**

prospects.name: Breathing to Crush Them

Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

Since you've been following the proper progression up to this point, we can really start to push you to your limits and beyond. Full Body 15 throws multiple Compound Sets at you, most of which are 30 seconds or longer. Focus on maintaining great form across all the back-to-back variations. It’s time to increase the external load, though, so you’ll need a band to redirect tension and build more eccentric loading into the movements. Ready to work hard? Level 4 will not disappoint in terms of overloading your chest, back, shoulders, arms, and core. prospects.name: Full Body 01
prospects.description:
_Want a strength training routine that covers all the bases? Our Full Body Strength series is exactly what you’re after, offering a well-rounded series of exercises that covers the lower body, core, posterior chain, and upper body. With a substantial progression, there’s enough here to keep you busy -- and improving -- for a very long time._

​

This is the first routine in the Full Body series. It introduces the most basic versions of moves that make up the majority of this program. Some of these moves may seem very basic but we encourage you to focus on perfect form and execution during these early levels so that when we turn up the heat you have things nailed. As you'll see, all the exercises at the lower levels will progress in a similar fashion going forward. We're building strength, but also fine-tuning your nervous system. As the program progresses you'll be asked to complete more difficult variations on each foundational move.

​

As with all the strength training routines, it helps if you’ve done a warm-up before getting started. That can be one of your favorite yoga routines, riding your bike on the trainer for 5-10 minutes, or doing a personal stretching routine.

​

Unsure if this is the correct strength level for you? [Click here for help.](https://wahoosystm.com/HelpCenterChooseStrengthLevel)

​

prospects.name: Run Focus 5
